DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Mass  Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma Histologic Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of tissue in which a carcinoma originated in any of the following anatomic sites: lip and oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, and salivary glands.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

Concepts.definition: Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

DataElementConcept.origin: CPTAC: Clinical Proteomic Tumor Analysis Consortium
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 2/14/20 jk Upd RD to "Qualified"; CPTAC released AI. 1/2/20 jk Released per CPTAC SME (Linda) for PRAD Baseline CRF. 7/26/19 jk Updated OC term to Tumor Mass; used on multiple CPTAC CRFs.  6/26/19 jk created for CPTAC Baseline CRFs.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma Histologic Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A squamous cell carcinoma that arises from any of the following anatomic sites: lip and oral cavity, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, and salivary glands._Refers to the type of tissue in which a tumor originated._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary growth pattern, acanthosis, mild cytologic atypia, and pushing tumor margins. The most commonly affected anatomic sites are the oral cavity, nasal cavity, larynx, esophagus, anus, vagina, vulva, and the plantar region of the foot.

Concepts.definition: A well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary growth pattern, acanthosis, mild cytologic atypia, and pushing tumor margins. The most commonly affected anatomic sites are the oral cavity, nasal cavity, larynx, esophagus, anus, vagina, vulva, and the plantar region of the foot.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Spindle Cell (Sarcomatoid) Squamous Cell Skin Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Spindle Cell (Sarcomatoid) Squamous Cell Skin Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A squamous cell carcinoma of the skin with a prominent spindle cell component.

Concepts.definition: A squamous cell carcinoma of the skin with a prominent spindle cell component.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary, exophytic growth pattern and hyperkeratosis. The most commonly affected anatomic sites are the larynx, penis, cervix, vagina, and vulva.

Concepts.definition: A well differentiated squamous cell carcinoma characterized by a papillary, exophytic growth pattern and hyperkeratosis. The most commonly affected anatomic sites are the larynx, penis, cervix, vagina, and vulva.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, scant amount of cytoplasm, and peripheral nuclear palisading.

Concepts.definition: A squamous cell carcinoma characterized by the presence of cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, scant amount of cytoplasm, and peripheral nuclear palisading.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma composed of malignant glandular cells and malignant squamous cells.

Concepts.definition: An invasive carcinoma composed of malignant glandular cells and malignant squamous cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A histologic variant of squamous cell carcinoma that arises from the skin. It is characterized by loosening of the intercellular bridges between the malignant cells which results in acantholysis.

Concepts.definition: A histologic variant of squamous cell carcinoma that arises from the skin. It is characterized by loosening of the intercellular bridges between the malignant cells which results in acantholysis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from squamous epithelial cells.  Morphologically, it is characterized by the proliferation of atypical, often pleomorphic squamous cells.  Squamous cell carcinomas are graded by the degree of cellular differentiation as well, moderately, or poorly differentiated.  Well differentiated carcinomas are usually associated with keratin production and the presence of intercellular bridges between adjacent cells.  Representative examples are lung squamous cell carcinoma, skin squamous cell carcinoma, and cervical squamous cell carcinoma.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
